entry.title: Integrating SAP Document Information Extraction (Document AI) with SAP CAP – Step by Step
entry.content:
Introduction :

In the SAP ecosystem, extracting meaningful data from documents such as invoices, contracts, or delivery notes—especially in accounting, finance, and operational processes—is often a manual and time-consuming task.Since these documents are usually in PDF or scanned image formats, using traditional data processing methods to identify fields is both error-prone and unsustainable in the long run.This is where SAP Document AI comes into play.By leveraging AI-powered models, Document AI can automatically analyze documents and extract key fields such as invoice number, date, currency, supplier–customer information, and line items.This eliminates the need for manual data entry, making the overall process faster, more reliable, and significantly more efficient.In this blog post, I will walk you through the step-by-step process of enabling SAP Document AI on SAP BTP and integrating it with a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) project.Starting from service activation, we’ll cover creating a service key, performing authentication (token retrieval), defining actions in CAP, uploading files, and storing the extracted Document AI results in a database.By the end of this guide, you’ll have a fully functional CAP endpoint that can be tested via Postman.You’ll learn how to send real PDF invoice files to Document AI and receive structured data in return—a foundation you can later extend with UI5 interfaces or workflow integrations.


Step 1 — Creating the Document AI Service in SAP BTP

First, we need to enable the Document AI service in SAP BTP. To do this:

  1. Log in to your SAP BTP subaccount.
  2. Open the Service Marketplace .
  3. Find the SAP Document AI Trial service under the Artificial Intelligence category .

On the service details page, you'll see the Overview and Service Plans tabs. Click Create to create a service instance .

Select the default plan . This plan enables basic API access in a trial environment and creates the instance your CAP project needs to connect to the Document AI service.

Fill out the form below:

  1. Service: SAP Document AI Trial Version
    → We will be using this service. Since it is a trial version, we will use the free trial quota.

  2. Plan: default
    → Only the default plan is available in the trial environment. It is sufficient for basic use.

  3. Runtime Environment: Cloud Foundry
    → Defines where the service will run. Cloud Foundry is often chosen for integration with CAP projects.

  4. Domain: dev
    → Select the Cloud Foundry domain where your project is located (for example, dev, test).

Instance Name: DocAI
→ You can give the service instance any name you want. This makes it easier to connect later (you can use lowercase, for example docai).

After filling in all the fields, you can click the Next button to proceed to the confirmation screens and complete the sample creation process.

Once the instance has been successfully created, the next step is to generate a Service Key for it . This key contains the authentication information needed for your CAP project to connect to the Document AI service.

  • Click the ellipsis ( … ) on the far right of your sample row .

  • Select Create Service Key from the menu .

In the dialog box:

 

  •  

    • In the Name field, enter a meaningful name such as DocAIKey .

    • You can leave the other settings at their default values.

    • Then click Create .

  • Once the Service Key is generated, click on its row to open the detail page.

After copying the JSON:

Adding Service Key details to the file To access .envthe Document AI service, we need to define credentials in our CAP project. To do this,
you can add a structure like the following to the file located in your project's root directory:.env

Correct the highlighted errors and try again.

Unsupported HTML code has been removed from your message. The HTML has been updated. Please review the message and send it when you are satisfied.

{
  "DOCAI_CLIENT_ID": "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
  "DOCAI_CLIENT_SECRET": "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
  "DOCAI_TOKEN_URL": "https://39c50baetrial.authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token",
  "DOCAI_URL": "https://aiservices-trial-dox.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/document-information-extraction/v1"
}

In real projects , instead of manually adding these details to the file .env, service keys are automatically linked to the application. This way, the application reads credentials from environment variables ( ) and is managed more securely. Automatic linking can also be achieved during deployment via MTA or manifest files VCAP_SERVICES.

service.cdsAction Definition in File

using { app as db } from '../db/schema';

service InvoiceService {
  entity Invoices as projection on db.Invoices;
  entity InvoiceItems as projection on db.InvoiceItems;

  action analyzeAndSave(file : LargeBinary, filename : String) returns {
     documentNumber : String(60);    
    documentDate   : Date;           
    currencyCode   : String(3);      
    senderName     : String(255);    
    receiverName   : String(255);   
    netAmount      : Decimal(15,2);  
    taxName        : String(40);     
    taxRate        : Decimal(5,2);   
    taxAmount      : Decimal(15,2);  
    grossAmount    : Decimal(15,2);  

  };
}

First, we define a CAP Action to send the PDF to the Document AI service and retrieve the result . This action can be triggered from the frontend or from tools like Postman.

For example, let's define an action with the following name :analyzeAndSave

  • filefield: Retrieves PDF file content in Base64 format.

  • filenamefield: Contains the file name.

  • returnssection: Returns key invoice fields from the AI ​​service (for example, documentNumber, documentDate, currencyCode, etc.).

This step creates the backend point that will trigger access to the Document AI service.

At this point, we need to listen for the action we defined in the backend . To do this , we add an event handler to . When the action is triggered, this handler sends the file to the Document AI service, retrieves the analysis result, and saves it to the database. The entire flow is managed within this function.analyzeAndSaveservice.cdssrv/service.js

module.exports = cds.service.impl(function () {
  this.on("analyzeAndSave", async (req) => {
    // We define the **helper functions required for the Document AI integration**.

  });
});

 

Obtaining a Token (Authentication)
Now that we've defined the service credentials in the file.env, we need to obtain an access token to send requests to the Document AI service.We'll add the following sample functionto our file:
getTokensrv/service.js

const axios = require("axios");

async function getToken() {
  const r = await axios.post(
    process.env.DOCAI_TOKEN_URL,
    new URLSearchParams({
      grant_type: "client_credentials",
      client_id: process.env.DOCAI_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.DOCAI_CLIENT_SECRET,
    }),
    { headers: { "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" } }
  );
  return r.data.access_token;
}

This function access_tokenreturns a value from the SAP Document AI service using the information in the file. This token will be used in subsequent API calls within the Authorization header ..env

In real projects, this step is often automated through target+service binding . The CAP application reads the necessary information VCAP_SERVICESfrom environment variables to obtain the token .

In this step, we retrieve the schemas defined in Document AI and
select the appropriate one for invoices. This allows the model to determine which fields to extract (e.g., Invoice ID, Date, Currency, etc.).

const schemas = await fetchSchemas(base, token);
console.log("[DocAI] schemas count =", schemas.length);

const chosen = pickInvoiceSchema(schemas);
if (!chosen) return req.error(500, "No invoice-related schema available in DOX");
console.log("[DocAI] chosen =", chosen);

 

    • fetchSchemas: Retrieves the schema list from DOX using the access token.

    • pickInvoiceSchema: Selects the schema whose name is invoice or contains the invoice .documentType

    • If none are found, return 500 (an obvious error to the developer).

    Base64 → Buffer conversion (prepare the file)
    The PDF file received from the client (UI5/Postman) may be in Base64 format. If it is a Data URL (for example,data:application/pdf;base64,...), remove the prefix and convert it to a true binary buffer.

let b64 = Buffer.isBuffer(file) ? null : String(file);
if (b64 && b64.startsWith("data:")) {
  const i = b64.indexOf("base64,");
  if (i > -1) b64 = b64.slice(i + "base64,".length);
}
const buffer = Buffer.isBuffer(file) ? file : Buffer.from(b64 || file, "base64");
console.log("[CHECK] filename=", filename, "buffer length=", buffer?.length);
if (!buffer?.length) return req.error(400, "Empty or invalid base64 file");

 

    • The field we will send via HTTP form-data needs to be binary ; therefore we convert the Base64 payload into a buffer .file

    • We return 400 (client error) for an empty or corrupt file .

    Create a job (submit with schemaId) We provide the selected schema and document type in , then submit the file to DocAI to start.
    options

const options = {
  clientId: "default",
  schemaId: chosen.id,
  documentType: chosen.documentType || "invoice",
};
console.log("[DocAI] submit options =", options);

const submitted = await submitJob(base, token, buffer, filename || "invoice.pdf", options);
const jobId = submitted?.id;
if (!jobId) throw new Error(`Job submit failed: ${JSON.stringify(submitted)}`);
console.log("[DocAI] jobId =", jobId);

    • schemaId: chosen.id→ we use a dynamic schema id.

    • If successful, it returns a jobId; we use this ID to track the status of the job.

    • If filenamenot provided the default value is "invoice.pdf".

    Question the work and get results

    • The job runs in the background. We poll at intervals until the status is COMPLETED .

    • Once the process is complete, the extracted areas become available under .extraction

const result = await pollJob(base, token, jobId, 60000, 1500);
console.log("[DocAI] status DONE, extraction keys =", Object.keys(result?.extraction || {}));

    • pollJob(base, token, jobId, 60000, 1500)→ 60 sec timeout / 1.5 sec interval .

    • Below and result.extractionyou get .headerFieldslineItems

    NOW LET'S GO TO TESTING:

    First, ...

cds watch --profile hybrid

Let's start our CAP project with the following command. (I started it this way because I chose HANA as the database .)

Sample Invoice PDF file:

 

Above is a sample PDF file we sent to the SAP Document AI service. The service automatically analyzes the invoice and extracts fields such as the invoice number, date, currency, supplier-customer information, and item information.

Testing with Postman:
Now that everything is ready on the backend, we can test the CAP action integrated with the Document AI service. To do this, use a REST client like Postman and send the following request:

  • Method: POST

    URL: http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/invoice/analyzeAndSave

    Body (JSON):

    • file name: Name of the PDF file to be uploaded

    • file: PDF file content in Base64 format

    In this answer:

    • The fields extracted by Document AI match exactly the action return types defined in service.cds.

    • These values ​​are also automatically saved to the HANA database in the background.

    In real projects, this setup isn't written manually. Instead, the Document AI service automatically connects to the CAP application via service binding . The application reads the necessary credentials directly from environment variables, and token acquisition is performed automatically in the background. This not only increases security (sensitive data like client secrets aren't visible in the code or repository) but also allows the application to run across different environments (dev, test, production) without additional configuration . During deployment, binding is provided via MTA or manifest files, and the application continues to run seamlessly with the same approach when deployed to production..envVCAP_SERVICES

 

Optional: Storing Raw Document AI JSON for Debugging:

 
 

In the Invoices entity of the schema , I defined a field called to store the original response returned by the Document AI service. This field is of type LargeString and holds all the header and line item data returned by Document AI in JSON format.RawJson

The purpose of this area:

  • Debug/Trace : Easily inspect the data returned by Document AI during development.

  • Extensibility : If I later want to add new fields or change the mapping structure, I can access the original source.

  • Data Traceability : Store raw invoice data so it can be reprocessed when necessary.

For example, when an invoice is processed, all the extraction data returned by Document AI is stored in this column. You can then open this data and clearly see which fields Document AI has recognized.

In this article, we explored how to enable SAP Document AI on SAP BTP and integrate it end-to-end with a CAP project. Each step—from creating the service instance and generating the service key to authenticating, defining CAP actions, and processing documents—represents a fundamental building block of a real-world backend automation setup.With this integration, you can now automatically process invoices or similar business documents without manual data entry. The extracted fields can be stored in your HANA database and then used for reporting, process automation, or analytics. This approach not only speeds up financial and operational workflows but also reduces human error and increases overall process reliability.In production environments, this setup is typically secured and automated through service binding, allowing applications to read credentials from environment variables without manual configuration. This ensures smooth operation across development, test, and production landscapes.As a next step, you can extend this backend integration with a SAP UI5 dashboard or management panel, enabling users to upload, view, validate, and approve invoices in real time. By doing so, you’ll move from a simple technical integration to a fully functional end-to-end intelligent document processing solution.

entry.title: Hands-on POC with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence is transforming how we design and extend SAP applications. Many SAP professionals are now exploring how to start working with AI inside the SAP ecosystem.
In this post, I share my hands-on experience with SAP AI Core, from my first steps to building a real Proof of Concept (POC) using low-code tools like Build Apps and BPA.

Since May, I’ve been working on a POC with SAP AI Core. At that time, I knew nothing about AI. Step by step, by practicing with the examples and samples provided by SAP, I managed to build several POCs integrating SAP AI Core with low-code tools.

The main objective is simple: accelerate development cycles and innovate with custom applications. On my roadmap, I focused on using low-code solutions like SAP Build Apps and Process Automation (BPA), while integrating AI agents to speed up processes.

Maybe in a future post I will share more details about the POCs I realized. But today, my first goal is to encourage SAP technical consultants to start this journey.

As a Senior SAP Technical Consultant, I realized that integrating an AI agent for a first POC or when consuming partner models does not require brand-new skills. But if the objective is to build and train your own model, then of course new competences are needed.

With SAP AI Core, we can easily integrate partner models (like Azure OpenAI, ChatGPT, etc.) through APIs. For most SAP technical profiles, it’s enough to follow a simple end-to-end example:

  • Select a partner model (text, image, etc.) in SAP AI Launchpad

  • Deploy it and get the URL

  • Configure the destination and start consuming your AI agent

Another option in SAP AI Launchpad is the Prompt Editor, which lets you create your own prompts on top of partner models. The key point here is security: your data is not stored in the model — it’s managed securely by SAP.

This means that integrating external AI agents is feasible without heavy upskilling.

But in my opinion, the real power of SAP AI Core comes when you train your own models. Of course, this requires upskilling in new environments and languages. The key here is HANA Vector combined with RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation). Together, they enable customers to enrich their knowledge databases and build custom agents that are more efficient, optimized, and deliver a brilliant user experience.

I believe that SAP AI Core will become a central part of the future SAP landscape, enabling faster innovation and smarter business processes.

  I’d love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP AI Core. Have you already built a POC or started exploring it?

entry.title: SAP BTP Awarded G2’s Fall 2025 Badges
entry.content:
Following a welcome long summer, Autumn has arrived and with it so have G2’s Fall badges. And continuing the trend of positive results, SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) has again been recognized with a number of badges, indicating that our wonderful customers continue to report good things about us.  

As ever, the SAP BTP team is thrilled to receive badges of recognition from G2, and thankful for the customer feedback that has led to us receiving these.

SAP BTP in our customers’ words

Reviews left on the G2 platform vary widely by industry and use case, as well as in terms of the length and detail that customers offer concerning their experience with the SAP BTP services that they use.

Looking through these reviews however reveals some interesting statements, which perhaps gives some indication concerning why they rate SAP BTP so highly:

“…overall, it's the best platform I have seen during my professional experience”  Engineer EE Software Sep 2025

“…the platform has boosted our operational efficiency, fostered better collaboration among teams, and sped up our digital transformation efforts”  Engineer, Oct 2025

“…this means fewer integration headaches, faster development of custom applications, and the ability to deliver solutions that are both agile and enterprise-ready”  Consultant, Sep 2025

“The primary benefit is having a single, unified platform to manage the entire lifecycle of a spare part order” Network Development Specialist, Sep 2025

“SAP BTP has helped us unify data and processes from multiple SAP and non-SAP systems without having to build complex integrations from scratch”  Associate, August 2025

“…it’s helped improve efficiency, reduce errors, and create a more connected, intelligent business environment”  July 2025

With positive statements like these concerning efficiency, agility and connectivity, SAP BTP is clearly hitting the mark with these customers. And this is simply a snapshot of the reviews available. 

I hope that you enjoy reading more SAP BTP customer reviews on the G2 Platform. And “thank you” to all of the SAP BTP customers who take time to leave reviews and comments for us with G2.

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: New Partner Content on SAP Business Accelerator Hub (Q3 ’25)
entry.content:
In continuation of our previous blog, we are excited to bring you the latest updates and maintain the momentum of delivering valuable insights to our community.

In this edition of our blog series, explore the newest content packages (particularly APIs and Integrations) released on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub by our partners in Q3 2025, along with their high-level details.

For complete details on each partner's content, refer to the partners listing which is available on the home page of SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Incture Technologies Private Limited

Integration packages published:

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central with Third Party CSR Vendor - Benevity

This package supports integration of business processes in your on-demand SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central system with your Third Party CSR Vendor - Benevity.

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central with Third Party Benefits Vendor - Bswift

This package supports integration of business processes in your on-demand SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central system with your Third Party Benefits Vendor - Bswift

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PiLog India Pvt Ltd

API package published:

PiLog Data Profiling

PiLog Data Profiling automates the process of examining and analyzing datasets to provide insights into their structure, quality, and content. It generates detailed HTML reports that highlight anomalies, missing values, patterns, and inconsistencies, enabling organizations to ensure data accuracy and suitability for use. This process is critical for data quality management, supporting data cleansing, validation, and preparation for advanced analytics or decision-making. By automating profiling, it minimizes manual effort, reduces errors, and accelerates data assessment for real-time insights.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ComZam Datentechnik GmbH

Integration package published:

SAP Customer Checkout Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud

The integration of SAP Customer Checkout with SAP S/4HANA Cloud features the replication of relevant master data to SAP Customer Checkout as well as posting Point of Sale transactions to SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Cobrainer GmbH

Integration package published:

SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub Integration with Cobrainer Job Architecture

This package contains artifacts that enable the various integration scenarios between SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub and Cobrainer Job Architecture.

Navigate to the package mentioned above to know more about those supported integration scenarios.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Figaf ApS

Integration packages published:

Figaf Azure DevOps Integration

The "Figaf Azure DevOps Integration" package provides a template for integrating Figaf and Azure. It includes highly configurable iFlows processing Figaf webhooks for ticket/transport events to Azure actions, update Figaf based on Azure changes, and a utility for searching issues.

Figaf Jira Integration

The "Figaf Jira Integration" package provides a template for integrating Figaf and Jira. It includes highly configurable iFlows processing Figaf webhooks for ticket/transport events to Jira actions, update Figaf based on Jira changes, and a utility for searching issues.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sodales Solutions Inc 

Integration packages published:

Microsoft Booking Integration with SAP HANA

This package integrates with the Microsoft Booking API, enabling you to create and retrieve booking information. It helps streamline workflows, reduce manual tasks, and provide a unified experience across platforms.

Microsoft Teams Integration with SAP HANA

The Microsoft Graph API for Teams chat allows businesses to automate and integrate their Microsoft Teams chat functionality with a wide range of other applications and services. With this API, developers can programmatically send, receive, and manage chat messages within Teams, enabling seamless communication between systems and users.

Microsoft Mail Integration with SAP HANA

The Microsoft Graph API for email enables businesses to automate and integrate their email systems with various applications and services. It allows developers to programmatically access and manage email messages, folders, and attachments in Office 365 mailboxes. 

SAP SFTP Employee Data with PGP Encryption-Decryption to SAP HANA

This package automates retrieving a CSV file from an SFTP server, encrypting specific fields, transforming the data into JSON format, and sending it to a defined receiver, such as SAP HANA. It ensures secure handling of sensitive data while converting it into a standardized format for downstream systems.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Rojo Consultancy B.V.

Integration package published:

SAP S/4HANA Integration with Zycus

Zycus Accelerator for SAP S/4HANA delivers a fully pre-configured integration solution to help you replicate Cost Center from S/4 HANA to Zycus.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SirionLabs Pte Ltd

Integration package published:

Sirion Contract Lifecycle Management Integration with SAP S4HANA

The Sirion Contract Lifecycle Management (CLM) Business Partner Replication Adapter for SAP S/4HANA seamlessly integrates supplier master data between SAP S/4HANA and Sirion CLM.  The Business Partner records initiated or updated in SAP S/4HANA are automatically replicated as Supplier profiles in Sirion CLM, ensuring alignment and consistency throughout sourcing and contracting workflows.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SPS Commerce

Integration package published:

SPS Commerce Supplier Integration with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

The SPS Commerce Fulfillment Connector for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud enables businesses to effortlessly automate and optimize electronic data interchange (EDI) with trading partners, streamlining order-to-cash processes and enhancing supply chain visibility. This cloud-based solution offers easy configuration, scalable performance, and a single connection to thousands of retailers, vendors, and logistics providers, reducing manual work and errors while supporting business growth.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PriceFx AG

Integration packages published:

 

SAP S/4HANA Exchange Rate Integration with Pricefx
 
This integration package contains integration flows to replicate exchange rates from SAP S/4HANA to Pricefx. They can be used as templates to speed up your integration between SAP S/4HANA and Pricefx. You could modify message mappings and value mappings according to your needs.
 
SAP S/4HANA Exchange Rate Mapping with Pricefx
 
This integration package contains sample mappings required to replicate exchange rates from SAP S/4HANA to Pricefx.
 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Microsoft Corporation

Integration package published:

 

Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP ERP and S/4HANA
 
Use the RISE certified Microsoft Sentinel solution for SAP applications to monitor your SAP systems any-premise with Microsoft Sentinel, detecting sophisticated threats throughout the business logic and application layers of your SAP applications. Use of Microsoft Security Copilot ensure fast time to response on SAP incidents.
 
The Microsoft Sentinel agentless data connector for SAP uses the SAP Cloud Connector and SAP Integration Suite to connect to your SAP Netweaver based systems and pull logs from it, as shown in the attached image.
 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 

If you are interested in Partnering with SAP Business Accelerator Hub, please refer to this section for more details. 

Stay tuned for further interesting updates and information by the end of this quarter!

entry.title: SAP BTP Developer's Guide: Extending Fiori Elements with the Flexible Programming Model
entry.content:
Are you leveraging the full potential of SAP Fiori Elements' Flexible Programming Model in your enterprise applications? While this powerful capability has been available for sometime now, many developers are still discovering how to effectively implement its extension points, building blocks, and controller extensions to solve real-world business requirements.

If you've been curious about extending your Fiori elements applications beyond standard floorplans but weren't sure where to start, the SAP BTP Developer's Guide offers a comprehensive learning path that covers this and much more.
 

What is the Flexible Programming Model ?

 

The Flexible Programming Model offers an extensive toolkit for extending Fiori elements applications beyond standard floorplans. It provides multiple ways to customize and enhance your applications while maintaining enterprise standards and framework compliance.
The Flexible Programming Model encompasses four main areas:
  • Extension Points: including custom sections, actions, columns, header facets, dialogs, form elements, filters, pages, views, and KPI tags.
  • Building Blocks: reusable fields such as forms, tables, charts, filter bars, and specialized controls that maintain framework compliance. These are consistently orchestrated by the framework, ensuring you automatically benefit from SAP Fiori compliance and standard application behavior like draft handling and side effects.
  • Controller Extensions: for customizing edit flows, state handling, routing, navigation, and message handling - allowing you to override specific methods to enable more flexibility while preserving framework functionality.
  • SAP Fiori Elements Advanced Features: including sophisticated capabilities like Side Effects for dynamic UI behavior, UI.Hidden annotations for conditional visibility, UI.PartOfPreview annotations for optimized data loading, and enhanced Value Help configurations for improved user experience.
When using the Flexible Programming Model to extend your Fiori elements applications, you automatically preserve all the enterprise-ready features that SAP Fiori Elements provides out of the box:
  • Accessibility
  • Internationalization
  • Mobile Compatibility
  • Performance Optimizations
  • Integration
  • Security
  • Lifecycle Stability
  • Test Automation Support
  • UX Consistency
  • and much more ...
The key advantage is that the Flexible Programming Model allows you to add custom functionality while maintaining all these enterprise features that would otherwise require significant manual implementation and ongoing maintenance in freestyle development.

Complementary Development Approaches

 

The SAP BTP Developer's Guide provides clear recommendations for building Fiori applications that balance rapid development with flexibility needs. Rather than viewing these as competing alternatives, the guide positions them as complementary approaches that work together to deliver consistent, enterprise-grade solutions.
 
 
Use SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 to benefit from a presentation of a common UI and UX. This approach provides the foundation for rapid development while ensuring consistency across your application portfolio. Personalization and theming are automatically supported, giving users the flexibility they need without additional development effort.

For more flexibility, use SAP Fiori element's Flexible Programming Model with or without SAPUI5 Freestyle. This approach allows you to extend beyond standard capabilities while maintaining the benefits of the Fiori elements framework. The Flexible Programming Model serves as the bridge between standard floorplans and complete customization.

SAP Fiori elements and SAPUI5 help you present one consistent solution experience to your customers, and you benefit from the upcoming designs and UX improvements automatically. This means your applications evolve with the platform without requiring manual updates to maintain modern standards.

Important consideration: Remember that even the simplest UI components or more complex ones like geographic maps have compliance requirements like accessibility and theming. When extending beyond standard Fiori elements capabilities, these requirements must be carefully maintained to ensure enterprise-grade applications.
 

Enterprise-Grade Development on SAP BTP

 

The SAP BTP Developer's Guide serves as the comprehensive starting point for developing business applications on SAP Business Technology Platform. It provides essential recommendations and best practices that help developers navigate the complexities of enterprise application development.
 
Within this guide, the mission Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP Application Following the SAP BTP Developer's Guide offers hands-on experience with critical enterprise development topics, including Change Tracking, Audit Logging, Attachments, Freestyle SAPUI5, Flexible Programming model and more.
 
While the mission covers multiple enterprise development aspects, the Flexible Programming Model section provides particularly valuable insights for developers looking to extend Fiori elements applications.
 
The learning scenarios are built around the Incident Management application, a practical business application where organizations can maintain and track incidents on behalf of their customers. This application already features a complete UI based on the SAP Fiori elements List Report Page floorplan, providing the perfect foundation to demonstrate how the Flexible Programming Model can enhance existing standard implementations.
The mission showcases several key extension capabilities that go beyond standard Fiori elements floorplans:
 
Extension Points: Custom Column
Learn to extend the Incidents table in the List Report Page with a custom column. This custom column demonstrates the integration of the MicroProcessFlow control, allowing processors to track incident progress directly within the table view.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Header Facet
Discover how to enhance the header section in the Object Page by adding a custom header facet. This implementation showcases the MicroProcessFlow control in the header area, providing processors with immediate visibility into incident progress.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Action
Implement a custom Location action in the Object Page that demonstrates practical integration of the GeoMap control. This custom action opens a dialog displaying customer locations, showing how to integrate specialized controls for business-specific functionality.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Section
Add a comprehensive Process Flow custom section to the Object Page. This section demonstrates the implementation of the ProcessFlow control, providing detailed visualization of incident workflows and status transitions.
 
 
Controller Extension
Learn to extend the Fiori Elements Object Page controller to customize standard behaviors. This section demonstrates how to override the edit flow while maintaining framework compliance and enterprise standards.
 
 

Conclusion

The mission Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP Application Following the SAP BTP Developer's Guide provides a comprehensive learning experience that goes beyond traditional tutorials. By combining Flexible Programming Model techniques with other essential enterprise development skills, you'll be equipped to build applications that meet real-world business requirements while maintaining the highest standards of enterprise software development.

Whether you're looking to extend existing Fiori elements applications or planning new enterprise solutions, this mission offers the practical, hands-on experience you need to master the art of enterprise application development on SAP BTP.
 
Happy Learning !

entry.title: MCP: A Comprehensive Guide
entry.content:
What You’ll Learn in this Guide

In this comprehensive guide to the Model Context Protocol (MCP), we explore how MCP simplifies AI integrations by standardizing the way AI systems connect with external tools and data sources.

By the end, you’ll understand how MCP transforms complex, one-off integrations into a seamless, interoperable ecosystem.

We’ll cover:

Why MCP: The Problem with AI Integrations
What is MCP
MCP Architecture: Host, Client, and Server
Demo

1) Why MCP

To understand why the Model Context Protocol (MCP) matters, we need to trace the evolution from LLMs to AI Agents, and then to MCP as the missing interoperability layer.

1.1 The Problem with LLMs

While powerful, Large Language Models (LLMs) have four critical limitations:

Outdated knowledge
No access to external or real-time data
Limited context windows
Risks of hallucination

1.2 From LLMs to AI Agents

To overcome these challenges, AI Agents emerged — capable of accessing tools, invoking APIs, and making real-time decisions.

However, this evolution created a new problem: integration complexity.
Each AI agent or application needed custom integrations with multiple APIs, data sources, and tools — leading to fragmented, brittle connections.

1.3 The Problem with Agents Accessing Tools

In the traditional approach, every model must directly integrate with every tool — an M×N problem.

Example:
3 AI models × 3 tools = 9 separate connections.
Each integration is custom-built and non-reusable, resulting in a fragile and hard-to-maintain web of connections.

This approach doesn’t scale. As the number of AI models and tools grows, integration overhead increases.

Solution — The MCP Approach

MCP replaces the M×N complexity with a simple, scalable M+N model.

Each AI model and each tool integrates once with the MCP layer.
This single standard interface allows any AI model to access any tool seamlessly — without custom connectors.

In short, MCP turns AI integration from a one-off engineering effort into a plug-and-play ecosystem for tools, data, and intelligence.

2) What is MCP

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is an open-source standard that defines how AI applications communicate with external systems through a unified interface.

It enables interoperability between different AI agents, tools, and platforms — regardless of their language, framework, or runtime environment.

With MCP, developers can build AI solutions that dynamically discover and invoke new tools securely and consistently.

3) MCP Architecture: Host, Client, and Server

MCP follows a client-server architecture similar to web protocols, but tailored for AI interaction.

It consists of three main components:

MCP Host — Manages and exposes available tools

MCP Client — Initiates requests to discover and use tools

MCP Server — Implements tool capabilities and exposes them to clients

3.1 MCP Server core capabilities

3.2 Interaction Model

The following diagram illustrates the interaction between the Host, MCP Server, and MCP Client.

This modular structure allows AI systems to dynamically discover, invoke, and orchestrate tools through a standardized layer — without direct coupling between tools and models.

3.3 Real-World Example: SAP MCP Servers

SAP has released MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers for CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model), UI5, and Fiori development environments.

With these MCP servers, AI agents can now assist developers contextually — understanding project structure, metadata, and domain models to offer precise, real-time help in CAP, Fiori, and UI5 projects.

This demonstrates how MCP can be embedded into enterprise ecosystems, bridging AI assistance with actual business development workflows.

4) Demo

The following demo illustrates these concepts in action:
https://github.com/pramodkumarmangu/mcp-demo

Demo 1 shows the integration challenges without MCP.
Demo 2 demonstrates how MCP simplifies integration and tool discovery through a unified protocol.

These demos make the shift from manual, fragile integrations to MCP-driven automation immediately clear.

Key Takeaways

MCP simplifies AI integrations by replacing point-to-point connections with a single standard interface.
Interoperability is built-in — any AI agent can use any MCP-compliant tool.
Scalability improves as new tools or models can be added without re-engineering integrations.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in September
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in September

Another month with two nice new release deliveries ✨

Learn more in my short top features video in September 2025 on YouTube 📺

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

My top features in September

 

Input Parameters in Task Chains and Transformation Flows

You can now define input parameters on the task level of task chains and also for transformation flows. A scheduled transformation flow uses the default value of the input parameter. Input parameters defined in transformation flows can be used in operators within the transformation flow, except for the Python operation in Apache Spark runtime.

A transformation flow executed as part of a task chain receives input parameters from the task chain. This will allow for more flexible usage of task chains and even nested task chains.

➡️  Creating a Transformation Flow

➡️  Creating Input Parameters in Task Chains

 

Email notification in Replication Flows

You can setup email notifications to stay informed when individual replication objects fail in a running replication flow. From both the Replication Flow editor or the Flows monitor, you can setup an email notification for failures of an individual object in a replication flow.

➡️  Configure Email Notification for Replication Flow Failure at Object Level

➡️  Working With Existing Replication Flow Runs

 

Fiscal Time Dimension

When creating a time dimension view, you now have the option for dimension type Standard and Fiscal Time. You use the new Fiscal Time dimension type to model your fiscal time periods and the columns that define their starts and ends. When you add a fiscal time dimension to an analytic model, a Fiscal Variant variable is created for this dimension. The variable can then be handled like any other variable. Its data type is derived from the fiscal variance column from the fiscal time dimension.

➡️  More information

 

Structure Support for Analytic Models

In order to create restrictions and calculations across all measures of an analytic model, you can create structures. Structures help you to save time and ensure consistency in your calculations, as you don’t need to create a formula/calculation for each measure. In the data preview, the structure members are displayed in their own section. When you use a structure member in the drill-down of a preview, the restriction and calculations defined in the structure member will be applied to each measure. Structures can also be used and enhanced in SAP Analytics Cloud. When the analytic model has measures and at least one structure you need to define how the calculations should be prioritized.

➡️  More information

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud Getting Started Series

 

Starting September 10, the Getting Started Series kicks off with four modules

  • Module 1: Build an Intelligent Application Grounded in Data Products (Sep 10, 2025)
  • Module 2: Fuel AI Innovation with SAP Databricks in Business Data Cloud (Sep 24, 2025)

👉Sign up today on the registration page.

 Check out the Step-By-Step Guide: Getting started with the SAP Business Data Cloud Basic Trial
